list_definition.definition: (of a deaf person) to understand what a person is saying by watching the movement of his lips.

list_ex_of_english: They can lip-read if they are close to somebody in a seminar or under individual tuition, but lectures are very different.
Without auditory input, a person with prelingual deafness is forced to acquire speech visually through lip-reading.
Lack of eye contact, not being able to see people's faces and not being able to lip-read were disturbing to most participants.
Acquiring spoken language through lip-reading alone is challenging for the deaf child because it does not always accurately represent speech sounds.
Deaf students take much longer over their work because they cannot lip-read in a lecture.
A deaf pupil who enters an ordinary tutorial has not only to lip-read, but has to try to follow the thread of a very involved argument.
Ordinary glass shines and makes it almost impossible to lip-read and so to understand what is being said.
However, they often rely on lip-reading even when they are using hearing aids.
